You are likely taking this class because of Robert Shiller. I thought the same going in. But please... don't do this. On the positive side, Shiller is an amazing human being. For someone as accomplished and distinguished as himself, he's so humble and nice to the class. He tries to get guest lecturers that are involved in the field, and this year, a few of us got to eat at Mory's for free with one of them. He also hosts two "salons," which are like 90-minute sessions where you and a few people in the class get to talk with him about economics and stuff. The value in Shiller is in his personal anecdotes, stories, and relationships, which are super cool to hear because he knows so many people of importance in this field. However, there are a lot of negatives. First, Shiller isn't a great lecturer. The slides are dry and sometimes not updated. If you didn't go to class, they are incomprehensible. Even if you were one of the few who went, the lecture is hard to follow. The lectures attempt to be historically-focused, but they are more like a hodgepodge of random facts that you're still expected to know for tests. Shiller doesn't teach math in lecture, and he asks his TAs to do so. They were helpful, but the lack of coordination between them and Shiller was awful for the students. We had such little expectations of what math or history to know going into tests because the TAs and Shiller didn't talk regularly. Ultimately, don't take this class for Shiller. Consider your sanity. Consider your sleep. And consider how much effort you want to put in by yourself, because this will be a self-teaching class. 

Also, the course was at 8:30 AM at the business school this year. That's a huge L. In addition to the class being super boring, you will also not be motivated to wake up, walk a long way to the business school, and pay attention for an hour. I feel like the percentage of people going to lecture went from 100% in the first week, to 50% by halfway, and 33% by the end of the year. It's really tough to see.

Take this course if you really really really want to be with Shiller, but even then I'd advise not to. Take this course if you're 100% confident in your ability to memorize a textbook and math formulas. But please be thoughtful in your decision. Yeah, Shiller was cool to be with, but it was not worth the effort in the end to say "I took a class with Robert Shiller."
